stem: Based on the provided patient data, select the most appropriate interventions and their rationale to address the patient's condition.
options: elevate the head of the bed
check the patient's blood glucose level
the patient is exhibiting signs of autonomic dysreflexia

blanks.correctOption: elevate the head of the bed
the patient is exhibiting signs of autonomic dysreflexia

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: 1400: S: Patient reports sudden onset headache and feeling flushed.  B: Patient is a 62-year-old male with a T6 spinal cord injury, admitted for routine skin assessment.  Usual BP is 110/70.  A: BP 180/100, HR 60, RR 18.  Patient denies pain other than headache.  Skin is warm and flushed above the level of the injury, pale and cool below.  Patient reports feeling anxious.  Lungs clear to auscultation.  Bowel movement yesterday.  Last void was 6 hours ago.  Catheter not in place. 1415: BP now 190/105, patient more agitated.  Assessed for bowel impaction, none found. 1420: Notified physician.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content:
1300: BP 112/72, HR 62, RR 16, SpO2 98% on room air.
1400: BP 180/100, HR 60, RR 18, SpO2 98% on room air.
1415: BP 190/105, HR 60, RR 18, SpO2 98% on room air.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: General: Anxious male in bed. Skin: Flushed and warm above T6 dermatome, cool and pale below. Neuro: Alert and oriented. Sensation intact above T6, absent below. Cardiovascular: Bradycardic, no murmurs. Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally. Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, bowel sounds present. GU: Bladder non-distended.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content: Monitor vital signs every 15 minutes. Assess for bladder distention. Assess for bowel impaction. Administer PRN antihypertensive medication for SBP > 180. Elevate head of bed if SBP > 150.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: PRN Hydralazine 10mg IVP for SBP > 180 mmHg. Not administered.

rationale.correct: Elevating the head of the bed helps to lower blood pressure by promoting venous pooling and reducing venous return to the heart. Recognizing autonomic dysreflexia is crucial because it's a potentially life-threatening condition requiring immediate intervention.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect answers do not directly address the immediate need to reduce blood pressure and manage the underlying cause of autonomic dysreflexia.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 1
answerBreakdown.content: Elevating the head of the bed is a crucial initial intervention because it helps lower blood pressure by decreasing venous return. This is a simple and rapid intervention that can be implemented while further assessment and treatment are initiated.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 2
answerBreakdown.content: Recognizing that the patient is experiencing autonomic dysreflexia is paramount. The sudden onset of hypertension, headache, and flushing above the level of injury, along with bradycardia, are classic signs of this condition. Prompt recognition allows for timely interventions to prevent severe complications such as stroke or seizure.

clinicalPearls: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency that requires prompt recognition and intervention.
Always assess for and address the underlying cause of autonomic dysreflexia, such as bladder distention or bowel impaction.
Elevating the head of the bed is a simple but effective initial intervention to lower blood pressure.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing an intervention without recognizing the underlying condition (autonomic dysreflexia) could lead to delayed or inappropriate treatment.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully assess the patient's signs and symptoms and correlate them with their medical history to identify the underlying condition before selecting interventions.

mnemonic.title: SIT UP
mnemonic.expansion: Symptoms (headache, flushing), Investigate cause, Take BP, Undo constrictive clothing, Provide treatment (elevate head)
